pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

Currently this uses `List.sum`, but it could also use `Nat.sum`. What's better?

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [e6642364a9](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17191/commits/e6642364a9b53b12ffc164b3a5858f87f70de98a)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Data.List.SplitLengths`|221|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ flatten_splitLengths`
`+ length_mem_splitLengths`
`+ length_splitLengths`
`+ length_splitLengths_getElem_eq`
`+ length_splitLengths_getElem_le`
`+ map_splitLengths_length`
`+ splitLengths`
`+ splitLengths_cons`
`+ splitLengths_length_getElem`
`+ splitLengths_nil`
`+ take_splitLength`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

> Currently this uses `List.sum`, but it could also use `Nat.sum`. What's better?


`List.sum` is fine!

One could prove stronger theorems. As long as the partial sums are big enough, the getElems have the right length.

One could even prove an unconditional result about the length of the i-th part, as a minimum.

(I wouldn't say these are strictly essential for this PR, but I do have a slight preference for getting the complete API in on the first go.)

> One could prove stronger theorems. As long as the partial sums are big enough, the getElems have the right length.
> 
> One could even prove an unconditional result about the length of the i-th part, as a minimum.
> 
> (I wouldn't say these are strictly essential for this PR, but I do have a slight preference for getting the complete API in on the first go.)

Isn't that `List.splitLengths_map_length`?

> > One could prove stronger theorems. As long as the partial sums are big enough, the getElems have the right length.
> > One could even prove an unconditional result about the length of the i-th part, as a minimum.
> > (I wouldn't say these are strictly essential for this PR, but I do have a slight preference for getting the complete API in on the first go.)
> 
> Isn't that `List.splitLengths_map_length`?

No, because that is only valid with the condition `l.length = sz.sum`. I want the unconditional lemmas.
@Command-Master any further thoughts on this one?

> @Command-Master any further thoughts on this one?

My apologies, I missed this. I still don't quite understand what statement are you looking for. Is it `(sz.take i).sum <= l.length -> (sz.splitLengths l)[i].length = sz[i]`?

> Currently this uses `List.sum`, but it could also use `Nat.sum`. What's better?

The latter is soon going away,it seems

> > @Command-Master any further thoughts on this one?
> 
> My apologies, I missed this. I still don't quite understand what statement are you looking for. Is it `(sz.take i).sum <= l.length -> (sz.splitLengths l)[i].length = sz[i]`?

Yes.
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Looks good to me. @kim-em, anything else you want to see here?

maintainer merge

Looks good to me. @kim-em, anything else you want to see here?

maintainer merge

I would suggest swapping the arguments. Given a list of lengths this is then a nice operator `List a \to List (List a)`. Also the fact that's the way the induction runs!

Dot notation will still work.

```suggestion
namespace List

/--
```
maybe?
Should this be `@[simp]` (or maybe in the other direction)?
I don't really see either direction being simpler, so maybe it's better to leave this un-simped if there's nothing for it to simplify.

```suggestion
theorem length_splitLengths : (sz.splitLengths l).length = sz.length := by
```
Out of curiosity, what's `â€¹âˆ€ (l : List Î±), _â€º` accomplishing here?
It's adding the induction hypothesis to the `simp`
Would it be cleaner to use the `induction ... with` syntax to name the inductive hypothesis explicitly?
Perhaps a minor detail, but I think it'd make more sense for the `List Î±` argument to go first. That way `l.splitLengths m` is "split `l` according to `m`" rather than the other way around.

That's how it was originally, but Kim suggested swapping it because
> Given a list of lengths this is then a nice operator List a \to List (List a). Also the fact that's the way the induction runs!

```suggestion
theorem map_splitLengths_length (h : sz.sum â‰¤ l.length) :
    (sz.splitLengths l).map length = sz := by
```
maybe?

pullRequest.title: feat(Data/List/SplitLengths): splitting a list to chunks of given sizes

source.title: feat(Archive/Ioi/Ioi2024Q2): a proof of the solution of question 2 from IOI 2024.
